notes: Welcome to the Winding Path Sangha (originally named the Iowa City Sangha). Founded on January 20, 2016, our community of lay practitioners follows the tradition of Vietnamese Buddhist teacher and peacemaker Thích Nh?t H?nh, who says there is no path to peace; peace is the path. Because we know that path can be winding and often challenging, and to support peace within ourselves and in the world, our Sangha gathers weekly to meditate, hear from teachings by Buddhist teacher Thích Nh?t H?nh and others, share about our practice, and discern together how to live fully in the present moment at home, at work, and in our community. Everyone is welcome, regardless of beliefs or previous experience with meditation, Buddhism, or mindfulness practices.

name: Wake Up Together
address: 4981 SE Woodstock Blvd, Portland, OR
notes: At Wake Up Together, our weekly sangha gatherings are a cornerstone of our community and a source of deep connection and inspiration. Here's what you can expect:1?? Engaging Dharma Talks: Our sangha gatherings feature insightful and uplifting Dharma talks delivered by our Order of Interbeing (OI) members. These talks offer practical teachings and guidance based on the wisdom of Thich Nhat Hanh and Plum Village. Be prepared to gain new perspectives, insights, and tools to apply mindfulness in your daily life.2?? Mindful Meditation: Each sangha gathering begins with a period of seated meditation. Together, we create a peaceful and supportive space where you can immerse yourself in the practice of mindfulness. Through guided meditation or silent sitting, you will have the opportunity to cultivate inner stillness, clarity, and presence.3?? Dharma Sharing: Heart-centered sharing is an integral part of our sangha gatherings. This is a safe and compassionate space where you can openly share your experiences, challenges, and insights related to your mindfulness practice. Through deep listening and mindful speaking, we create a supportive community where everyone feels seen, heard, and understood.4?? Connection and Community: Our sangha gatherings provide a wonderful opportunity to connect with like-minded individuals who share a common interest in mindfulness and conscious living. You'll have the chance to meet and build relationships with fellow practitioners, fostering a sense of belonging and support on your spiritual journey.5?? Mindful Rituals: Throughout the sangha gatherings, we incorporate mindful rituals that enrich the experience and deepen our connection with the present moment. These rituals can include reciting the Five Mindfulness Trainings, engaging in mindful walking, or other practices that cultivate mindfulness and reverence.6?? Inspired Action: Our sangha gatherings are not just about personal reflection and growth; they also inspire us to take mindful action in our lives and communities. We explore ways to integrate mindfulness and compassion into our daily actions, and discuss opportunities for collective engagement and service.In summary, our weekly sangha gatherings at Wake Up Together provide a nurturing space for deepening your mindfulness practice, engaging in meaningful conversations, and connecting with a supportive community. It's a place where you can find inspiration, guidance, and a sense of belonging as you continue your journey of awakening and transformation.

name: 3 Jewels Sangha
address: Fort Worth, TX, 76133,  United States
notes: I am starting a new sangha as a way to reach people in need of a beloved community. We are only meeting online currently but I hope to have a physical space where we can practice in person. I am hoping to build a community steeped in the Plum Village tradition and growing an OI team to support many local in person people, but also offering our current virtual meetings either as a hybrid meeting or separate way to reach remote connections seeking a solid community focused on mindful living and engaged buddhism. We currently are doing book studies (currently We Were Made For These Times book) and basic sitting meditation. My goal is to build a regular weekly practice of Sitting, Walking, Silent meditation, followed by a Dharma Talk (using books, articles, or videos by Thay and others) to offer a deeper lesson then community discussion time to share. I'd like to offer tea in our discussion time. As we grow I would like to start having Quarterly Days of Mindfulness. I would eventually like to build an annual retreat for the DFW community as we do not have anything like this locally yet. I will be leaning on OI and Dharma Teachers when we get to that stage but right now it is only myself facilitating.

address: First Universalist Society of Franklin, 262 Chestnut St, Franklin, MA 02038, United States
notes: We are dedicated to mindful living and engaged Buddhist practice. You do not have to be a Buddhist to practice with us. Many members continue to participate in other religious traditions while attending sangha. All are welcome.We practice mindfulness inspired by Vietnamese Buddhist monk Thich Nhat Hanh. The foundation for our being together is the Five Mindfulness Trainings, which are the Buddhas teachings on the basis for a happy life.Our community practices mindful living in order to help reduce suffering while increasing joy, harmony and peace in ourselves, in our community and in the world. Mindfulness is the energy of being aware and awake to the present moment. It is the continuous practice of touching life deeply in every moment. To be mindful is to be truly alive, present and at one with those around you and with what you are doing. We bring our body and mind into harmony while we wash the dishes, drive the car or interacting with family, friends and colleaguesOur Practice includes:Mindful BreathingSitting MeditationWalking MeditationDharma SharingDharma talks

address: Roscommon Drive, Fort Wayne, IN 46805  United States
notes: Flowering Smiles Sangha practices engaged Buddhism in the Plum Village tradition. We are open to all ages and all people. We meet Wednesday nights from 7 to 8:30. We are exploring the Sutra on the Full Awareness of Breathing while cultivating a loving kindness relationship within ourselves, nurturing our compassion from insights and growing awareness of the three doors of liberation. We'll watch a Plum Village video or read from one of Thay's books.  This is followed by a discussion to clarify the day's topic, relate it to the full discourse as a whole and how it supports our daily mindful practice.  We transition this knowledge with intent upon experiencing the topic through meditation.  Lastly, we have dharma sharing about our meditative experience and new awareness.

name: Mindfulness Community of Hampton Roads

notes: The Mindfulness Community of Hampton Roads was founded in May 1992. Its mission is to provide a sangha, or community, to support those who practice Buddhism in Norfolk and elsewhere in Hampton Roads. Although formation of the Mindfulness Community of Hampton Roads was inspired by the teachings of Thich Nhat Hanh, it became evident soon after its inception that there was a need to expand its scope to embrace the support of practitioners from all Buddhist traditions, as well as those who practice secular mindfulness and have an interest in Buddhism.
